column4: Is it possible to unmount a drive via Gnome? Everytime I try it states, Unable to unmount, only root can unmount.
you can actually just edit your fstab and make it user mountable and umountable
I thought there was a way to adjust that. Are you familar w/ what you stated? Do you know the correct syntax or can you point me in the right direction

Yeah I know how to do it, you will need to pop up a terminal and cd to /etc and then type sudo nano -w fstab to edit fstab , what kind of device are you trying to make unmountable, is it a removable drive or one thats sata/ide?
its SATA in this particular machine, I have my drive partition 4 times and  I have 2 windows based partitions that i dont want mounted
Do you want them mounted sometimes or never?
I have one I don't mounted @ all, and I'd like to mount the other when need be.
alright, well umount them both now, then edit your fstab by popping up a terminal and typing cd /etc then typing sudo nano -w fstab then you will see all your mounts on your system
It doesn't do much, just disables wrapping of long lines
Cool thx
in the fstab you see your drives and stuff, all your mounts on your system, and then you see your ntfs mounts, under <options> do the ntfs ones say defaults or do they have more than just that?
more than that
what exactly does one of them say?
ntfs    defaults,nls=utf8,umask=007,gid=46 0       1
Alright, add this, do this line, defaults,nls=utf8,umask=007,gid=46,user
Just add user at the end like that to both of them
And what ntfs partition did you not want mounted ever, was it the main one? And do you recognize which one it is in your fstab?
ntfs    defaults,nls=utf8,umask=007,gid=46 0       1    <-- Do I add it after the numerical 1 OR add comma and then add user w/o spaces
good question let me double check
Before the 0 after gid=46 so it would be gid=46,user
I don't have to map to /media/ right? I can map anywhere I have created a folder?
Also, in fstab the type of one of the drives is NTFS, but in gparted it states its a FAT32
Yeah you can mount any drive anywhere as long as there is a directory there in place for it to put all its contents into
